line_1: Prove every Fool to be a Poet.
line_2: By Demonstration Ned can show it:

line_1: A Grecian constable took up the poet;
line_2: "A libel this — I'll make the mummer know it. "

line_1: That their wandering cousin is turn'd out a poet;
line_2: For surely 'tis right my relations should know it,

line_1: Ends both the spider and the poet.
line_2: Perhaps our deaths may better shew it;

line_1: That my new Mistress is a Poet;
line_2: For Oh, I guess — nay more I know it,

line_1: Was it a Muse, O lofty Poet,
line_2: Some Folks are drunk, yet do not know it:

line_1: Than a noisy nonsensical half-witted poet.
line_2: And let me be rather but honest with no-wit,

line_1: Is both a Herald and a Poet,
line_2: V— (for 'tis fit the Reader know it)

line_1: "I sent you to Latin, he makes you a Poet:
line_2: "He uses me ill, and the World shall know it;

line_1: But the gods, who will never abandon a poet,
line_2: As oft has been said, condescended to show it,

line_1: A wicked imp they call a poet,
line_2: (By this time all the parish know it)
'Her air and all her manners show it.

line_1: Himself is, out of doubt, a poet.
line_2: And, tho' before he did not know it,

line_1: For a prophet is often a poet.
line_2: We know you have wit if you'd shew it,

line_1: Believe me in earnest, though acting the poet,
line_2: My break feels the smart, and mine actions do shew it.
